newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Ravers flock to Europe's number two techno fest.
newsitem.headline: Ravers flock to Europe's number two techno fest.

text.p: Up to half a million people were expected to swamp Zurich for the annual techno music Street Parade on Saturday, Europe's second-largest techno festival after the Berlin Love Parade.

Techno fans, called ravers, in flashy costumes or scantily clad for hot weather, started arriving on Friday from across Europe for the five-hour parade by 30 booming sound trucks along five km (three miles) of the city's lakefront.
When the parade ends on Saturday evening, ravers can choose between 30 all-night techno parties in sites ranging from the main train station to a forest clearing above the city.
"It has all been peaceful so far," said a police spokesman in Zurich, Switzerland's biggest city with about one million inhabitants in the wider metropolitan area.
Techno music is a mix of thundering beats and repetitive electronic bleats supplied by disc jockeys equipped with massive sound systems.

Zurich's Street Parade started in 1992, three years after Berlin's Love Parade, and has grown from around 2,000 dedicated ravers the first time to a mix of dancers and spectators that last year totalled about 300,000 people.
Berlin's Love Parade on July 12 drew up to a million people.

The Zurich festival under the motto "Love, peace and tolerance" is also a financial wellspring, generating sales estimated at around 50 million Swiss francs ($30 million) for everything from music CDs to railroad tickets. ($ = 1.506 Swiss Francs)
